Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Gravitational-Wave Detector Characterization and Science Education in the Advanced LIGO Era
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award supports an integrated research and education program by the PI and his students at California State University Fullerton (CSUF) aimed at hastening the direct detection of gravitational waves with the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO). The research is focused on i) a thorough characterization of the Advanced LIGO instruments, especially the identification and removal of noise artifacts in the data that could mask or mimic potential astrophysical signals, and ii) measurement and analysis of scattered light from optical materials that are important for extending Advanced LIGO's reach. The outreach component of this award will establish a pathway for students at nearby community colleges to learn about and become part of the PI's research group. This project will also increase science literacy through the development and dissemination of educational materials for learning gravitational-wave science in the undergraduate curriculum.

Albert Einstein predicted gravitational waves in his 1916 theory of general relativity. Nearly a century later, we are poised to directly detect these waves for the first time, and to observe the universe in an entirely new spectrum. LIGO is an NSF-funded project to measure gravitational waves from astrophysical systems such as colliding black holes and neutron stars. This award supports research to thoroughly characterize the LIGO detectors - work essential for the detection of gravitational waves. In addition, it supports research on optical scatter aimed at assessing and improving the quality of commercial optics that will be required to extend the astrophysical reach of future gravitational-wave detectors. These projects provide increased opportunities for students to participate in cutting-edge research at CSUF, a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution. The education and outreach components of this award will engage students, many from groups currently underrepresented in physics and astronomy, in the discovery-ready field of gravitational-wave science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Albert Einstein predicted gravitational waves, ripples in spacetime, a century ago. In 2015, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) harnessed this new “sense” for humanity by observing gravitational waves from merging black holes. These discoveries revealed a population of black holes with masses tens of times that of the sun and tested relativity theory with extreme gravity. In 2017, LIGO, its European partner Virgo, and the broader astronomical community debuted multi-messenger gravitational-wave astronomy by observing a neutron star merger with electromagnetic counterparts. This discovery connected gamma-ray-bursts to neutron star mergers, measured the speed of gravity, and probed the matter within neutron stars. 

In this CAREER project, researchers from California State University Fullerton (CSUF) helped LIGO to make and interpret these discoveries. We identified and removed sources of transient noise in the detectors, helped to understand and improve the quality of optical materials, created and implemented new gravitational-wave educational materials, and trained students to join the next generation of gravitational-wave scientists and the STEM workforce.

I was on the six-member team that coordinated the paper announcing LIGO’s first gravitational-wave observation. Our team collected input from the wider collaboration and distilled this into a concise article, perhaps our field’s most significant single paper. I also reviewed data quality, figures and procedures for the announced discoveries of the black hole merger GW170814 and the neutron star merger GW170817. 

My group was centrally involved in efforts to improve the quality of the LIGO data to increase the rate and fidelity of observations. Until 2015, I led the LIGO Collaboration’s Detector Characterization Group, and represented this group on the LIGO Executive Committee. My group continued to develop and use the Hierarchical Veto algorithm to identify the causes of transient noise in the instruments. We identified and helped improve issues with LIGO’s data quality during its first engineering and observing runs and helped show that the gravitational-wave events were not caused by terrestrial noise. Additionally, we contributed to studies of environmental influences on LIGO data and designed a set of non-magnetic rigid tripod mounts that reduced spurious signals from the LIGO magnetometers.

The astronomical reach of gravitational-wave observatories relies on the highest quality optics with very low optical loss. To identify current limitations in state-of-the-art optics, my group and collaborators further developed a highly sensitive instrument to measure and images light scattering (an imaging scatterometer).  Our results and their associated publications provided scattering levels and deeper understanding of the optical physics for i) the primary mirrors for LIGO, ii) optics that will allow the use of quantum squeezed states of light in upgrades to LIGO, iiI) LIGO antireflection fused silica windows, and iv) crystalline coatings that may be used to greatly extend the range of future gravitational-wave detectors. 

Education and cognitive research has shown that interactivity is key to student learning of scientific concepts. Astronomy 101 is one of the most widely taken general education science courses and is the last formal science course taken by many college students. This project supported the development, testing, and public release of interactive materials (clicker questions, ranking tasks, and lecture materials) that promote student engagement with gravitational-wave astronomy concepts in the astronomy 101 classroom. 

This project involved undergraduate and masters students from CSUF, a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution, in gravitational-wave research, education, and outreach. These students conducted research in optics, detector characterization, and education and took part in the first direct observations of gravitational waves. These experiences, the connections made, and the transferable skills developed have helped the participating students secure industry and PhD positions. Most of the students that took part in these activities were from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in physics.
